title: Yukon Territory is an unmistakable source of Canadian history
text:
Yukon Territory is an unmistakable source of Canadian history and a gold mine of family fun By Linda Bates, Postmedia News July 3, 2015 7:13 PM The historical, narrow-gauge White Pass and Yukon Railroad covers the ground the early prospectors took from Skagway, Alaska, to Whitehorse. Photograph by: chilkoot , Fotolia 
When parents and grandparents are planning a family vacation, many think south, yet there’s a terrific family destination the other direction, way up north in Yukon . 
There are places to learn about Canadian history in a fun way, indoor and outdoor attractions that the whole family can enjoy, and best of all, a relaxed, friendly atmosphere with no crowds and no lineups. Prices for flights from Vancouver, car rental and accommodation are reasonable too. It’s an easy two-and-a-half hour flight, and of course there is no border to cross or money to change. In the summer, temperatures average in the mid 20s. Whitehorse is an attractive small city of 25,000 with a pretty setting on the Yukon River. Kids love the little narrow-gauge Waterfront Trolley, a refurbished 1925 trolley that runs back and forth along a 10-kilometre stretch of the Yukon River. It’s a hop-on, hop-off trip, and it stops at the restored SS Klondike, one of the sternwheeler riverboats that in the early 20th century plied the Yukon River from Whitehorse to Dawson City. Another stop is at the brand new Kwanlin Dun Cultural Centre , an impressive facility that celebrates the art and culture of the local First Nations people. 
Also just a hop off the tram is the MacBride Museum , with photos, artifacts and displays about the gold rush. Here kids can try their hand at gold panning. 
Beside the train is a part of the 5.5-km Millennium Trail , a flat circular trail through park and forest that travels both sides of the Yukon River. It’s an easy walk or bike ride for the whole family, with bike rentals readily available. From the trail you can walk to the Whitehorse Fish Ladder at the Yukon River dam, the longest wooden fish ladder in the world, and watch Yukon River chinook salmon and other species from underground viewing windows. 
Near the airport, just 10 minutes from town, is the bite-sized Beringia Interpretive Centre . The ancient land of Beringia – which was a land bridge between what is now Siberia and Alaska – was a place of ice, huge mammals and the first people of North America. Glaciers never formed there because it was too dry. It was home to the giants of the Ice Age: the woolly mammoth, the giant short-faced bear, the steppe bison and the scimitar cat. All are on display at the museum. 
I think even the most jaded young urbanite would put down the smartphone long enough to gasp at the sight of the 5.5-metre-tall mammoth skeleton, or the long short-faced bear, which weighed 660 kilograms and, when it stood up, could reach nearly 6.5 metres, about a metre taller than a basketball hoop. When it’s time to get out of the city, the Yukon Wildlife Preserve , just 25 minutes from Whitehorse, is a 285-hectare stretch of native animals including woodland caribou, Canada lynx, Rocky Mountain elk, mountain goats, moose, mule deer, wood bison, muskoxen, Arctic foxes and more. Take time for a stop at Bean North Coffee Roasting , a delightful place set in a wooded location just past the Yukon Wildlife Preserve, with organic fair trade coffee, delicious home baking, soups and paninis. 
If the budget allows, there are two terrific ways to see more of the Whitehorse area: by train and by plane. 
The historical, narrow-gauge White Pass and Yukon Railroad covers the ground the early prospectors took from Skagway, Alaska, to Whitehorse. The train no longer goes all the way to Whitehorse, but a motorcoach takes passengers to Fraser on Bennett Lake, where they pick up the train to Skagway. After a two-hour layover, the train returns to either Fraser or Carcross, Yukon, where passengers board the bus back to Whitehorse. The scenery is spectacular, and rich in history. (Take your passport for this trip, since it goes into the U.S.) 
For a real treat, Alpine Aviation runs flightseeing tours from Schwatka Lake in Whitehorse to the Chilkoot Pass, Kluane National Park, and more. We took a four-passenger Cessna float plane over the mountains and glaciers to Fraser, where the White Pass train begins. There we landed and encountered parties of hikers just coming off the famous Chilkoot Trail, following the path of the prospectors. Nothing is left of the once-bustling town of Fraser but the picturesque church, built as an ecumenical church and community centre to support the people who passed through. 
IF YOU GO 
The Whitehorse Waterfront Trolley is open from May 15 to Sept. 15. A round-trip ticket is $5 and children under five are free. 
The MacBride Museum is open year-round. Cost is $10 for adults and $5 for children, or $25 per family. 
The Kwanlin Dun Cultural Centre is open year-round on weekdays. Admission is by donation. 
The Beringia Interpretive Centre is open year-round. Admission is $6 for adults and $4 for children. 
Yukon Wildlife Preserve has various rates but the best deal is $35 for a family self-guided tour or $50 for a 90-minute guided bus tour. 
The White Pass and Yukon Railroad offers trips of various lengths and prices. The daylong trip from Whitehorse to Skagway and back is 10 hours long, including a two-hour stop in Skagway, and costs $141 per adult and $70.50 per child. The beauty, combined with the history of the route, is unmatched. 
Alpine Aviation offers flightseeing trips of various prices. The 2 ½-hour flight over the Chilkoot glaciers and Chilkoot Pass to Bennett Lake and Fraser, B.C., costs about $250 per person for a party of four. There are shorter, less expensive trips available. 
Air North , Yukon’s official airline, offers good prices and packages to Whitehorse. Air Canada also flies to Whitehorse. For more information, visit travelyukon.com . © Copyright (c) Postmedia Network Inc.
